Award.AwardTitle: Next-Generation Materials for Plasmonics and Spintronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
The mission of the University of Utah's Center of Excellence for Materials Research and Innovation (Utah CEMRI*) on Next Generation Materials for Plasmonics and Organic Spintronics is to foster interdisciplinary basic research on new materials, develop the underlying theoretical and experimental science, train the next generation of scientists, create curiosity and excitement in Science, Math, and Engineering among the nation's youth, transmit the knowledge to the broadest possible segments of our society, and lay the foundation of the next generation science and technology that will revolutionize society. This will be accomplished through a number of research, educational and outreach programs.

The Utah CEMRI includes two interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs), namely Plasmonic Metamaterials from the Terahertz to the Ultraviolet (IRG 1), and Organic Spintronics (IRG 2). IRG 1 will focus on understanding and exploiting the properties of surface plasmon polaritons in artificially structured materials (metamaterials) across a broad range of the electromagnetic spectrum. The goals of IRG 1 include creatingnew optical tools, materials and device architectures in the THz spectral range, demonstrating the applicability of magneto-plasmons to improve spin injection into organic semiconductors and developing capabilities for plasmon-enhanced UV resonant optical spectroscopies. IRG 2 will focus on understanding and manipulating spin excitations in several different spin-related organic devices, including organic spin-valves, spin-organic light emitting diodes, and spin-enhanced organic photovoltaics for solar energy harvesting. Using fundamental electrical, optical and magnetic studies, the primary goal of this group is to enhance basic understanding of spin interactions in organic materials, including hyperfine, spin-orbit and exchange. These studies will be used to develop spin-based organic light emitting diodes, which have applications in magnetic memory and displays, and low-cost organic photovoltaic cells with enhanced conversion efficiency for solar energy. Seed projects will be funded through a competitive peer review process with a goal of leading the Center into emerging transformative research areas and forming the basis of a new future IRG. All research projects will be regularly reviewed on a competitive basis to maintain high levels of scientific excellence, collaboration and productivity. In order to expand the scope of research and broaden the research perspectives of graduate students and post-docs, Utah CEMRI members will actively engage in substantive collaborations with universities, industry and national labs in the US and abroad. The results of research will be published in high quality, high impact refereed journals.

An important role of the Utah CEMRI is to broaden participation in the research endeavor. This involves actively working to increase the diversity among students, post-docs and faculty members, with increased participation from members of under-represented groups. The Utah CEMRI will implement educational and outreach activities designed to impact K-12 students, teachers (RET), undergraduate students (REU), underrepresented groups, and broad segments of society through active participation of all center members. These activities include an annual Science Olympiad, Discover Engineering program for high school students, Partner School Program for K-12 students, Hi-GEAR (Girls Engineering Abilities Realized) summer camp for female high school students, ACCESS program to encourage women to pursue Science, and REU and RET programs. All major diversity, education, and outreach programs will be regularly assessed to ensure their efficacy and impact.


*An NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC)

Project Outcome Report

University of Utah Materials Science and Engineering Center

Next-Generation Materials for Plasmonics & Organic Spintronics

NSF-DMR-1121252

The vision of the University of Utah MRSEC is to foster interdisciplinary, basic research on new materials; develop high caliber theoretical and experimental science; train the next generation of scientists; create curiosity and excitement in STEM disciplines among youth; and transmit this knowledge broadly.

During the 2011-2018 funding cycle, research efforts were organized into two IRGs. In addition, Seed Projects explored potentially transformative topics including: topological and 2D materials, electrochemical interfaces, materials with strong spin-orbit coupling, and materials for energy conversion and harvesting. These projects either broaden the scope of existing IRG-efforts or set new directions for collaborative research (i.e. future IRGs) and are typically funded for one to two years.

IRG 1 Plasmonic Metamaterials: The central mission was to push the boundaries of plasmonic materials research by developing novel concepts, capabilities, devices, and technologies in the relatively unexplored THz and UV spectral regimes. In the UV regime, we focused on Al, Mg, and Ga and their alloys, and novel methods of depositing and patterning these materials into functional devices. We developed a method to create patternable thin films of Ga (which exists in a near liquid state at room temperature), optimized the plasmonic properties of Al-Mg alloys at specific UV wavelengths, and revealed the influence of Ga alloying on Al and Mg nanostructures nano-patterned with FIB. We also developed bottom-up methods of patterning Al films to produce nanocrescent structures and roughened surfaces with large plasmonic enhancement in the UV. Surface-enhanced fluorescence and Raman spectroscopies were used to quantify plasmonic enhancements in Al and Mg nanostructures. In the THz regime, we investigated the properties of a number of exotic materials; integrated many of these materials into active devices; and created a number of metamaterial structures exhibiting novel physical effects such as Anderson localization, negative refractive index, and multi-level information encoding. Materials work included liquid metals, materials with spatially-varying conductivity, 2-D materials including graphene and MoS2, and 2-D and 3-D methylammonium lead trihalide perovskites. Novel THz modulators and tunable filters were demonstrated with these materials alone or in combination with metamaterial structures for enhanced performance.

IRG 2 Organic Spintronics: The primary goal was to enhance the fundamental knowledge of spin interactions in organic materials, including hyperfine, spin-orbit and exchange interactions. To achieve this goal, fundamental electrical, optical and magnetic studies were performed. These studies were used to develop spin-based organic light emitting diodes, which have applications in magnetic memory and displays, and low-cost organic photovoltaic cells with enhanced conversion efficiency for solar energy. The project also helped in understanding and manipulating spin excitations in a variety of spin-related organic devices, including organic spin-valves, spin-organic light emitting diodes, and spin-enhanced organic photovoltaics for solar energy harvesting. Efficient techniques of injecting and detecting spin-polarized carriers in semiconductors were developed. Research also lead to the development of a single-spin detection microscope that allows for measurement of the spin of individual localized paramagnetic states such as the spin state of individual polarons on polymer chains.

Education and Human Resources: Our mission remained consistent: recruit and train the next generation of diverse scientists, mathematicians, and engineers in materials science and engineering. Our approach was to create a pipeline into engineering and science through engagement with the next generation of materials researchers by generating enthusiasm for science and engineering though K-12 outreach programs, creating opportunities to participate in materials science and engineering research at the undergraduate level, facilitating development in communication of materials research at the graduate level, and facilitating leadership in materials discovery through a post-doctoral mentorship program. Increasing diversity has been a major consideration in the design of all outreach and education programs of the Utah MRSEC. The legacy established by MRSEC is evidenced by the fact that many of our programs continue without MRSEC support. As an example, Science Olympiad continues to operate under the auspices of the College of Engineering. Several of the smaller efforts are being written into other center-level proposals through the Office of the Vice President for Research. The Center has had significant impact on how assessment is done on campus. As other REU programs were funded on campus, coordinators sought assessment guidance from the MRSEC program. Best practices, established in undergraduate research assessment, will carry on throughout campus - largely due to lessons learned and continual improvement of the MRSEC REU program throughout the award period.

Diversity: Diversity efforts focused on recruiting, retaining, mentoring and graduating students, post-doctoral fellows and faculty in MRSEC-related programs. The overall diversity among participants throughout 2011-2018 included: 29 tenure-track faculty (five female, three URM); 24 Post-docs (seven female, no URM); and 44 graduate students (14 female, three URM). Further, we hired three new faculty (two female, two URM) associated with MRSEC.
